title: Leicester Mercury published Business Review of the Year 2016 - September to December
text:
Business Review of the Year 2016 - September to December By Leicester Mercury | Posted: December 30, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Leicester's iconic Irish store which is set to close down Business Review of the Year 2016 - September to December X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
September 
Turnover and profits at a county financial services business jumped substantially on the back of organic growth, acquisitions and a broader range of services. Mattioli Woods grew 25 per cent in the year to May 31, with revenue up to £43 million from £34.6 million a year earlier. The specialist wealth management and employee benefits business also the purchase of West Midlands pensions business MC Trustees for £2.2 million. 
Read more: Mattioli Woods boss says UK economy is robust enough to enable Brexit to happen 
Lifestyle clothing chain Joules said it had had a "transformational" year after profits jumped 41 per cent on the back of a 14 per cent rise in sales. 
Joules, based in Market Harborough, saw annual sales rise to £131 million for the year to the end of May, up from £116 million for the same time last year. 
Growth was driven by a leap in online demand of more than 17 per cent, following the relaunch of its website a year ago. 
Shop sales were also up a healthy 13 per cent after opening 10 new stores. 
Tom Joule, the founder of Joules 
The Coalville based developer said the average selling price of its homes rose more than 10 per cent in 2016, to £289,800, showing house hunters remain keen to secure deals. 
October 
A senior executive at Barratt Developments was suspended following his arrest. 
The Coalville-based housebuilder said it suspended Alastair Baird, its regional managing director for London after he was arrested over possible misdemeanors in awarding contracts for new housing developments. 
A Barratt development in Leicestershire 
Caterpillar (UK) laid off 113 staff at its Desford depot. Caterpillar said all the workers affected were leaving voluntarily and the business – which has faced a drop in global orders – had managed to avoid compulsory redundancies. 
Kaby Engineers, based in Upper Charnwood Street, in Leicester, wrote to its staff last month warning of up to 90 potential redundancies. 
Read more: Up to 90 jobs at risk at Kaby Engineers 
Employees received a letter from the firm's managing director Baljinder Sanghera outlining the issues facing the company and the measures it needs to take to counter them. 
He wrote: "The outlook is decidedly worrying, and, based on early projections the company will need to realise substantial cost savings to remain sustainable in the long term." 
Cars that could cruise down motorways while the driver checks their e-mails or reads a paper are being trialed on a county test track. 
Cars that drive themselves and talk to each other are being tested at the Horiba MIRA vehicle testing facility, at Higham on the Hill, near Hinckley. 
Read more: Driverless cars being tested in Leicestershire months away from hitting the road 
November 
Leicester City chief executive Susan Whelan was named Business Executive of the Year at a glittering awards ceremony. 
She was named top executive at a large business and then received the overall prize at the Leicester Mercury Business Executive of the Year Awards. 
Susan has helped transform Leicester City from Championship also-rans to Premier League champions and, now, Champions League contenders. 
She is also boss of the hugely successful Thai-based King Power duty free business. 
Read more: LCFC boss: "Maybe I'll end up in the North Pole doing something very unusual...' 
Lord Simon Wolfson, the chief executive of fashion giant Next plc 
The retailer said in-store sales of full priced items were down 5.9 per cent in July, August and September, compared to the same time last year. 
However it said "October sales improved significantly".
